news.title: Mthuli Struggles To Defend Sinking ZiG
news.content:
By Business Reporter  Desperate to project optimism in the face of economic turmoil, Finance Minister Professor Mthuli Ncube on Thursday presented the 2025 Mid-Term Budget Review Statement at the new Parliament Building in Mt Hampden. He reviewed the ZiG$270 billion National Budget despite growing public frustration with the worsening cost of living, a rapidly deteriorating currency, and a government seemingly out of touch with reality.

Professor Ncube claimed Zimbabwe remained in growth mode, citing what he called positive developments during the first half of the year  despite overwhelming evidence pointing to a collapsing economy, with the recently introduced Zimbabwe Gold (ZiG) currency already failing to restore market confidence or curb inflation.

Given the positive economic developments during the period January to June, we are confident that the projected economic growth of six percent in the 2025 National Budget is achievable, Ncube said. All sectors are expected to record positive growth in 2025, mainly on account of a favourable agriculture season, improved electricity generation, and a stable exchange and inflation rate  notwithstanding declining international mineral commodity prices and a subdued global economic climate.

However, Ncubes upbeat tone contrasts sharply with on-the-ground realities: runaway prices in ZiG, shortages of basic goods, and mounting pressure on businesses and households amid an unconvincing monetary reform process. The ZiG, launched in April 2024 to replace the depreciated Zimbabwe dollar, has struggled to gain traction as both retailers and the public continue to rely heavily on the US dollar.

Zimbabwes economic problems are rooted in long-term structural weaknesses, including a bloated public sector, weak industrial base, heavy reliance on mining exports, and widespread corruption. According to economists, the frequent currency changes and arbitrary policy shifts have deepened public distrust in formal financial systems.

The minister claimed that government reforms would enhance the ease of doing business and create a competitive economic environment. Government has, with immediate effect, begun reviewing various fees and charges. In addition, the number of bureaucratic steps and compliance requirements will be drastically reduced. On the fiscal front, the Government will continue to review the existing tax system with a view to reducing observed distortions and granting a supportive regime for business growth and competitiveness, he said.

He added that policy consistency would be key to maintaining stability. Mr Speaker Sir, the country has enjoyed economic stability during the first half of the year, and I want to assure Honourable Members that both fiscal and monetary authorities are going to stay in that mode. We cannot afford any policy slippages.

Yet critics argue that policy slippages have already become the norm. From introducing the ZiG without broad consultation to forcing citizens to pay some taxes in a barely usable local currency, the government has continued to implement inconsistent and often contradictory fiscal and monetary measures.

Key highlights from the 2025 Mid-Term Budget Review include:

Zimbabwes economy has long been weighed down by political instability, disputed elections, and tight state control over key economic levers. While the official narrative talks of growth and reform, ordinary Zimbabweans continue to grapple with rising unemployment, deteriorating public services, and a shrinking formal economy.

news.title: Zim National Grabs Top SA Water Job, Faces Xenophobia
news.content:
By A Correspondent  Polokwane A highly qualified Zimbabwean engineer, Kennedy Chihota, has come under fire from some South African political parties and residents following his appointment as Director of Water and Sanitation in the Polokwane Municipality.

Despite the backlash, Mayor John Mpe has defended the decision, stating it was based on professional merit and the urgent need to fix the citys water infrastructure challenges  not on nationality or politics.

Chihota is a professionally registered engineer with the Engineering Council of South Africa (ECSA) and boasts an impressive academic and professional background. He holds a Bachelors Degree in Civil Engineering and four Masters Degrees in:

Chihota also brings decades of experience in both academic and practical engineering roles. He previously served as a senior lecturer at the University of Limpopo and held key municipal positions including:

Speaking at Peter Mokaba Stadium, Mayor Mpe underscored that Chihotas appointment is part of a broader strategy to address persistent water backlogs, improve infrastructure, and ensure service delivery across Polokwane.

Were not experimenting. Were hiring based on proven experience and capability, said Mpe. Mr. Chihotas record speaks for itself. Our focus is delivery, not where someone was born.

However, political groups such as the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) and ActionSA have criticised the move, arguing that such top jobs should be reserved for South Africans, especially in the face of poor service delivery in areas like Seshego and Mankweng.

The appointment has also exposed growing tensions within the municipality. Reports suggest disagreements between the City Manager and some councillors over hiring processes, staff promotions, and alleged irregularities in financial management.

While the backlash appears to be fuelled in part by growing anti-immigrant sentiment, the municipality insists that it cannot afford to compromise on service delivery by sidelining skilled professionals on the basis of nationality.

news.title: White South Africans Have Migrated To Zimbabwe Saying It’s Safer, Way Better
news.content:
VIRAL PODCAST CLIP IGNITES DEBATE OVER ZIMBABWES BUSINESS REALITY VS PERCEPTION

By Dorrothy Moyo | July 29, 2025.

Zimbabwes Global Image vs On-the-Ground Reality (whose podcast is this? Tag the producers name below)Speaker 1:I just feel like Zimbabwe has become a sort of running gag now when people talk about failed states or basket cases. The name comes up all over the world. I waspic.twitter.com/Qpo4T0VCTt

A short clip from a recent podcast has gone viral, spotlighting a provocative conversation about Zimbabwe and its reputation. Speakers argue that while Zimbabwe is frequently portrayed alongside Venezuela as a failed state or basket case, the lived experienceespecially for some white South African migrants (whove relocated to Zim)paints a more nuanced picture.

 Podcast Claims in Focus

The podcast dialogue criticises the global habit of naming Zimbabwe and Venezuela when discussing failed states, contending that this perception overlooks pockets of stability in Zimbabwe where safety, infrastructure, and economic activity persist.

The speakers board flights to Harare regularly, noting their fellow white Afrikaner passengers commonly work in mining and infrastructure, enjoying what one describes as a quality of life thats second to none.

 What Published Opinion Shows

Zimbabwe as a Racial Fantasy or a Real Place

Scholar Percy Zvomuya criticises external narratives that treat Zimbabwe as a blank canvas for projections from outsidersespecially South Africansrather than acknowledging its own diverse realities. He writes:

Zimbabwe is its own self, its own country, not some echo chamber from which people hope to catch reverberated strains of their own discourses .

This resonates with the podcast critique: Zimbabwes image is too often dominated by external tropes rather than grounded in complex internal realities.

White Zimbabwean Experience and Privilege

Reports on the white community in Zimbabwe highlight how colonial legacies shaped privilege. As historian Chris McGreal observed in The Observer (2008), before Mugabes land seizures, white Zimbabweans kept their houses and their pools and their servants and benefitted from booming farm revenues . That pattern left deep social and economic stratification long after independence.

Despite harsh land reforms, white professionals and business-oriented migrantsincluding South Africanshave often remained influential in key sectors such as mining, agriculture, and infrastructure, especially via contractual leases or investments. Some sources note troubled conditions for poorer whites after farm seizures, in contrast to an elite minority maintaining comfort .

 Context Matters: Limitations of the Narrative

While the podcast depicts genuine aspectssuch as foreign investment and relative safety in certain enclavesit skips over broader systemic issues:

 Analysis: Where Perception Meets Reality

The viral clip touches on genuine phenomenasome white South African migrants have found niches in Zimbabwes remaining economic sectors, and there are enclaves of relative safety in major cities. But this doesnt reflect the national picture. Published commentary and research underscore a history of racial inequity, economically motivated land redistribution, and a pattern of privileged continuity for a tiny minority.

 Broader Takeaways

This discussion reminds readers that context and diversity of experiences matter. Zimbabwes image as a failed state may resonate globally, but realities on the ground reveal complexityand caution against simplistic narratives.

Podcast Summary: Zimbabwes Global Image vs On-the-Ground Reality

Speaker 1:

I just feel like Zimbabwe has become a sort of running gag now when people talk about failed states or basket cases. The name comes up all over the world. I was listening to a podcast the other day, and when the conversation turned to collapsed economies, it wasnt Afghanistan or Libya that dominated the discussionit was Venezuela and Zimbabwe. These are the two countries that always get mentioned.

Speaker 2:

True, but ironically, there are many things in Zimbabwe that actually work better than in some so-called developed countries.

Speaker 1:

Well, you go there often. And I go there often too, as you know. For example, I feel perfectly safe walking the streets of HarareI dont worry about getting mugged. Thats something I cant say for some cities out here.

Speaker 2:

And there are parts of Zimbabwe where people are living in absolute comfortenjoying fabulous lifestyles. Im specifically talking about white South Africans who have moved to Zimbabwe and now enjoy a quality of life thats arguably second to none.

Speaker 1:

Yes, and speaking of development, we have a friend in asset management who also travels to Zimbabwe a lot. She talks about the infrastructure projects happening there and the kinds of investments Zimbabwe is still managing to attractespecially in the energy and mining sectors.

Speaker 2:

Exactly. And just to add to thatevery time I fly to Zimbabwe, the flights are always packed with white Afrikaners, most of whom are involved in mining and infrastructure projects. That tells you something.

news.title: Police Name Bindura Manjuzu Drowning Victims
news.content:
By Crime and Courts Reporter  Police have released the names of two women who drowned during a suspected Manjuzu traditional ceremony at Nyaure River in Manhenga Village, Bindura.

The victims were identified as Ellen Mlauzi (49) and Ethel Nyabundu (22). They had attended the ceremony in the company of Pauline Kadzviti (48), Tabeth Sagwidza (39), Emma Sagwidza (35), and a man identified as Jacob Peter.

The group is reported to have been conducting traditional rites when tragedy struck.

Manjuzu, commonly associated with mermaid spirits in Zimbabwean spiritual belief systems, are thought by followers to bring wealth, beauty, and prosperity. The practice has gained popularity, particularly among women seeking better fortunes in life. However, concerns persist over the spiritual and physical dangers involved in these rituals, especially those performed near water bodies.

National police spokesperson Commissioner Paul Nyathi confirmed the incident.

The Zimbabwe Republic Police confirms the drowning of two women at Nyaure River, Manhenga Village, Bindura, he said. The deceased were reportedly conducting traditional rituals with two other women and one man.

According to police reports, one of the women began displaying signs of spiritual possession, moved into deep water, and drowned. The man attempted to rescue her but failed. In the ensuing panic, another woman also drowned. One body was retrieved shortly after the incident, while the other was recovered the following day by the police Sub-Aqua Unit.

Comm Nyathi urged the public to exercise extreme caution near water bodies.

We continue to urge members of the public to avoid engaging in life-threatening activities in rivers and dams. This tragic loss of life could have been prevented, he said.

The practice of Manjuzu initiation continues to spark debate. While some adherents claim to have experienced prosperity, others warn of spiritual consequences. Several women involved in such practices say they were chosen by the spirits and did not actively seek them out.

One self-identified Manjuzu follower from Chitungwiza claimed the spirits had brought nothing but fortune to her life:Since realising I have a water spirit, Ive never faced any misfortune. Everything is going well for me, she said, dismissing claims that the practice is harmful or linked to witchcraft. Its not evil. Christians are just misinformed.

Another woman, speaking anonymously, said:These things came to meI didnt look for them. I was chosen. I see visions, and I live with this gift I didnt ask for.

However, religious leaders such as Apostle Bigboy Kathumba warn that water spirit practices are linked to anti-marriage curses and short-lived material wealth.

This spirit is influencing even churches and pastors. Some young people, including men with no clear source of income, are falling under its spell, said Kathumba. There are spiritual signs when someone is possessed by njuzu spirits.

Police say investigations into the Bindura drownings are ongoing.

news.title: No Power, No Teachers, No Clinics—But Mavetera Gives Them Starlink
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Information Communication Technology Minister Tatenda Mavetera has hailed the deployment of Starlink internet kits to Zimbabwes rural district councils as a major step in bridging the digital dividebut critics say the move reeks of misplaced priorities in a country where basic public services are in shambles.

In a statement issued Wednesday, Mavetera announced that her ministry had distributed both computers and Starlink kits to all rural local authorities, claiming it was part of a broader push toward nationwide digital inclusion.

As we journey towards our digital transformation agenda of empowering every corner through ICT services in Zimbabwe, our Ministry deployed firstly computers and secondly Starlink kits to all our Rural District Councils and local authorities, she said.

She went on to declare that no village should be left offline, portraying the rollout as a key milestone toward achieving the governments Vision 2030 agenda.

But for communities that still lack electricity, healthcare facilities, qualified teachers, and even clean drinking water, the introduction of satellite internet is being met with more confusion than celebration.

Critics argue that flashy technology projects mean little in rural councils where dilapidated clinics operate without nurses, schools have no textbooks or toilets, and entire wards go for weeks without power.

Starlink kits will bridge connectivity gaps in our rural district councils, Mavetera insisted, yet offered no plan for how these kits will function in areas with no power or trained personnel to manage them.

To make matters worse, Starlink itself has operated in a legal grey area in Zimbabwe. The government previously warned against the use of the Elon Musk-owned satellite service, and there has been no official statement on the current legal framework or procurement process behind this sudden nationwide rollout.

In an apparent effort to frame the initiative as a broader reform drive, Mavetera also pointed to a sensitisation workshop conducted by the Ministry of Local Government and Public Works. The workshop included the launch of aMinimum Service Delivery Standards Dashboard, a digital tool meant to track real-time government performance.

However, many observers view the dashboard as yet another symbolic gesture with little bearing on the daily struggles faced by rural populations. Data dashboards, they say, wont patch potholes, deliver medication, or fix broken boreholes.

These efforts are about closing the digital divide and fueling #Vision2030 through #DigitalizeZimbabwe, Mavetera addedwords that increasingly ring hollow for citizens confronting daily service delivery failures.

As the government continues to trumpet digital transformation, Zimbabweans are left wondering why leaders are prioritising internet kits over real, tangible improvements in their lives.

news.title: Horror As Prophet’s Ritual Leaves Two Women Dead
news.content:
By A Correspondent

A spiritual cleansing ritual at Nyaure River in Bindura turned into a nightmare after two women drowned while attempting to summon mermaid spirits, known locally as manjuzu. The incident, led by a self-styled prophet, has stunned the local community and provoked outrage from traditional leaders who accuse untrained spiritualists of endangering lives through reckless and unauthorised ceremonies.

According to State media, the two victims were part of a group of five young women who had accompanied the prophet to the sacred river in Chief Masemburas area for what was meant to be a spiritual awakening.

The ritual, however, descended into chaos after one of the women allegedly got taken by the spiritsprompting a frantic and ultimately fatal rescue attempt.

Explaining the ordeal to ZBC News, the prophet said:I went with some women to pray and I wanted to invoke the mermaid spirits. These people had their own issues and during this process one of us was taken by the spirits. We then went into the water to try and rescue her and one of them died. In the process, my wife also died during the rescue.

The incident has drawn criticism from traditional authorities, who condemned the unsanctioned ritual and failure to follow proper spiritual protocols.

These are sacred waters, and there are underground spiritual creatures there, said Headman Masembura.Every time you go there you must follow proper rituals and consult with the local leaders. We asked this prophet what he was doing, and he said he brought rice, sweets, biscuits and wine to appease the mermaid spirits of their deceased colleague. In this river, we have never heard of mermaidsbut spiritual things are hard to understand.

Belief in manjuzumystical river beings thought to grant wealth, beauty, or famehas grown in popularity, especially among young women. But spiritual elders warn that the practices are being misused and manipulated by opportunists.

Traditional healer Sekuru Nzou said:The thing that has happened here is shocking. Some people just say we are mermaids but there are procedures to be followed. People who go to rivers with others must have spiritual eyesight.

He explained that there are different types of manjuzu, including manjuzu enhope, who communicate through dreams and collect river medicine, and others believed to attract prosperity. However, he warned of the dangers of counterfeit rituals.Some people buy fake mermaid spirits and use magic which may lead them into Satanism, he added.

Nyasha Simon, a marine spirit believer, echoed the warnings.Manjuzu are real, but many of us young women are abusing them or being conned by fake prophets. If you go to the river with a hidden agenda, you can end up drowning because the spirits will reject you.

The tragedy has reignited debate over the legitimacy and regulation of African spiritual practices in Zimbabwe. As traditional leaders call for vigilance and respect for ancestral customs, the Bindura community continues to grieve a spiritual journey that ended in death.
